Title: "Advanced Filtering Techniques in Azure Search: A Practical Guide"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdf295841         ],         "crs": {             "type": "name",             "properties": {                 "name": "EPSG:4326"             }         }     },     "Address": {         "StreetAddress": "1450 Ala Moana Blvd 2238 Ala Moana Ctr",        "City": "Honolulu",         "StateProvince": "HI",         "PostalCode": "96814",         "Country": "USA"     }, Example 3: Filter on textPOST /indexes/hotels-sample-index/docs/search?
api-version=2020-06-30 {     "search": "art tours",     "queryType": "simple",     "filter": "Category eq 'Resort and Spa'",     "select": "HotelId,HotelName,Description,Category",     "count": true } Response for the above query is scoped to only those hotels categorized as "Report andSpa", and that include the terms "art" or "tours".
In this case, there's just one match.JSONFilter expressions can include "search.ismatch" and "search.ismatchscoring" functions,allowing you to build a search query within the filter. This filter expression uses awildcard on free to select amenities including free wifi, free parking, and so forth.HTTPResponse for the above query matches on 19 hotels that offer free amenities. Noticethat the search score is a uniform "1.0" throughout the results. This is because thesearch expression is null or empty, resulting in verbatim filter matches, but no full textsearch. Relevance scores are only returned on full text search. If you're using filterswithout "search", make sure you have sufficient sortable fields so that you can controlsearch rank.JSON{     "@search.score": 2.8576312,     "HotelId": "31",     "HotelName": "Santa Fe Stay",     "Description": "Nestled on six beautifully landscaped acres, located 2 blocks from the Plaza.
